tasks.task: Research and discuss blue tongue virus transmission and the role of biting midges.
subtasks: Understand the non-contagious nature of blue tongue virus.
Explain how the biting midge (Culicoides sp.) acts as a biological vector for blue tongue virus.
Describe the viral replication process within the midge and its transmission to non-infected hosts.
Analyze the challenges of controlling blue tongue virus spread due to midge movement.
Recognize the importance of early detection and local management of vector-borne diseases.

tasks.task: Describe the role of animal studies in blue tongue virus research.
subtasks: Justify the use of infected ruminants (sheep, goats, cattle) in research studies.
Explain the monitoring and treatment practices for study animals in isolation units.
Discuss the limitations of non-animal research methods for studying viral transmission.
Outline the methods used to collect and analyze midge saliva in blue tongue virus research.

tasks.task: Address ethical considerations and alternatives in blue tongue virus research.
subtasks: Acknowledge the necessity of animal research for complex biological questions.
Highlight ongoing efforts to reduce animal use through cell cultures and organ models.
Discuss the ethical trade-offs between advancing knowledge and minimizing animal use.

tasks.task: Examine the complexity of blue tongue virus variants and vaccine development.
subtasks: Explain the 27 serotypes of blue tongue virus and their implications for vaccination.
Describe the challenges in creating a cross-serotype protective vaccine.
Detail the types of vaccines used in blue tongue virus control (inactivated, live attenuated) and their limitations.
Discuss the role of genetic reassortment in virus variation and immune evasion.
Analyze the importance of strain monitoring and characterizing new outbreaks.
